results.summary: Passengers on the lower deck of a bus where a girl was stabbed to death heard screaming but thought it was teenagers messing about, police say.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/6b47b337-8f98-404a-b57d-438b81e879d0"><image id="66252167"/><paragraph role="introduction">Passengers on the lower deck of a bus where a girl was stabbed to death heard screaming but thought it was teenagers messing about, police have said.</paragraph><paragraph>Officers said they believed the attack on Christina Edkins during Thursday morning's rush hour in Birmingham appeared to be "random and senseless".</paragraph><paragraph>A 22-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murdering the 16-year-old who was attacked on the bus's top deck.</paragraph><paragraph>Police said they were still searching for the murder weapon.</paragraph><paragraph>Officers have until 01:00 GMT on Saturday either to charge or release the man they have in custody.</paragraph><crosshead>Three people</crosshead><paragraph>They said the suspect, a British national with links to Walsall, was not known to mental health units in the area and has no known link to the teenager.</paragraph><paragraph>Christina was stabbed once in the chest on the bus on Hagley Road while on her way to school in Halesowen.</paragraph><paragraph>A woman claiming to have witnessed the attack on the bus said she waited for the girl's attacker to get off the vehicle before performing CPR on the teenager.</paragraph><image id="66275743"/><paragraph>Writing on Facebook, Stephanie Bent said: "I gave CPR until medics arrived and am deeply traumatised I could not save her. I certainly wasn't going to confront a knifeman knowing he had just stabbed someone I thought he may stab me too, all I cared about was getting up to the girl to help."</paragraph><paragraph>Police have said they "urgently" need to speak to all of the 16 people who were on the bus at the time of the attack, at about 07:30 GMT.</paragraph><paragraph>In a press conference Det Supt Richard Baker said police have been "overwhelmed" by the public response, which had provided the investigation with "crucial information".</paragraph><paragraph>He said there had been three people on the top deck of the bus at the time of the attack - Christina, her attacker and another man, who has been identified.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Baker said the suspect "calmly waited to get off the bus" after Christina was attacked. </paragraph><paragraph>Detectives called for anyone who might have seen the suspect travelling on buses around the Birmingham area after the stabbing to get in touch.</paragraph><crosshead>Floral tributes</crosshead><paragraph>Counsellors have been brought into Leasowes High School, where Christina was a pupil, to support pupils and staff.</paragraph><paragraph>Throughout the day, pupils and people living nearby have been leaving flowers, soft toys and balloons outside the school gates.</paragraph><paragraph>The school said it thanked "everyone for many offers of support" and extended heartfelt sympathy to Christina's family.</paragraph><paragraph>Friends of the teenager also gathered to pay their respects at Hagley Road, where a growing number of floral tributes have also been placed.</paragraph><paragraph>A book of remembrance has been opened at nearby St Peter's Church, in Lapal, Halesowen, where people can go to light a candle.</paragraph><paragraph>Several supermarkets in Halesowen have started collections for Christina's family.</paragraph></body>
